instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board clean, no liquid.
Light on charger but no chime etc.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> extremely HOT.
Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> - still short.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>/4 no short

Then removed <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> to check from what side is the short and short was on <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR>/1.
Next removed <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> and short was on <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>/1

<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> no short on <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/5 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/4 but removed just in case.

<CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR>/1 no short.

Removed <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7045</CAPACITOR> - still short.
Removed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> - still short. Before removing chcked resistnace between pin 27/28 and 17/18 and was OK.

Got no other ideas :(
Anyone can help?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I'm assuming you removed F7040 and F7041 and confirmed the short is on pin 1. If <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> was getting hot, you need to replace it, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR>, and the ISL all at the same time. Remove those four and see if the short goes away.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: F7040 and F7041 removed - short on both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Short on both sides is baaad... Inject voltage on system side and see what heats up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ew yeah what Duke said that's no fun
